title: Plotting-Players
text: Since fpl package hosted Github, need download “remotes” package.

title: Plotting-Players
text: official Premier League API ‘https://fantasy.premierleague.com/api/bootstrap-static/’ using function get_premier_stats() output player data data.frame can analyzed selected additional packages -built R scripts. example finding top 10 scoring players given position.
code: # Download Premier League Data premier_data <- get_premier_stats() # Grabs current Premier League Data  # Filter data by players players <- filter_players(premier_data, get_photos = F) # use default photos on # Sample of player data head(players[c("team", "web_name", "form", "points_per_game", "cost", "position",  "goals_scored")]) #>   team     web_name form points_per_game cost position goals_scored #> 1  ARS Fábio Vieira  0.0             0.0  5.4      MID            0 #> 2  ARS      G.Jesus  3.2             2.5  6.7      FWD            3 #> 3  ARS      Gabriel  2.4             4.2  6.4      DEF            3 #> 4  ARS      Havertz  3.0             4.3  7.8      FWD            8 #> 5  ARS         Hein  0.0             0.0  4.0      GKP            0 #> 6  ARS     J.Timber  2.6             3.5  5.6      DEF            1 # Select position forwards <- players[players$position == "FWD",] # selecting using data.frame methods  # Order the forwards column_order <- order(forwards$goals_scored, decreasing = TRUE) # Create organize data.frame  forwards_ordered <- forwards[column_order,] # Goals Scored head(forwards_ordered[1:6]) # Select first 6 cols to display #>     team web_name form points_per_game cost position #> 464  MCI  Haaland  5.8             6.0 14.8      FWD #> 535  NEW     Isak  8.0             6.8  9.5      FWD #> 584  NFO     Wood  8.6             6.1  7.1      FWD #> 65   AVL  Watkins  6.2             5.0  8.9      FWD #> 141  BRE    Wissa  4.6             5.2  6.2      FWD #> 722  WOL    Cunha  3.2             5.4  6.9      FWD

title: Plotting-Players
code: # Another way to order columns with an additional package: data.table library(data.table)  # Add data.table functionality with data.table players_dt <- data.table(players) # order by points per game, selected first 6 columns for display ordered_forwards <- players_dt[position == "FWD", ][order(-points_per_game)] # Points Per Game head(ordered_forwards[,1:6]) # Select first 6 cols to display - data.table way #>      team web_name  form points_per_game  cost position #>    <char>   <char> <num>           <num> <num>   <char> #> 1:    NEW     Isak   8.0             6.8   9.5      FWD #> 2:    NFO     Wood   8.6             6.1   7.1      FWD #> 3:    MCI  Haaland   5.8             6.0  14.8      FWD #> 4:    WOL    Cunha   3.2             5.4   6.9      FWD #> 5:    BRE    Wissa   4.6             5.2   6.2      FWD #> 6:    AVL  Watkins   6.2             5.0   8.9      FWD

title: Plotting-Players
text: primary things remember plotting look names columns present.

what: Choose two columns you want to plot
title: Plotting-Players
text: example, plot “cost” versus “total_points”, grouping forwards, displaying players name. Note: “smart” matching inputting columns, works best can input exactly column names. take seconds depending group. plots may overlapping points, many players!

text: Note: photos might missing

previous_headings: Choose two columns you want to plot
title: Plotting-Players
text: plotting function works almost subset players data.frame. , can subset remove players table plot! especially case midfielders. Top percent filters total_points.
code: fpl_plot(players, "cost", y = "form", group = "names", pos = "MID", top_percent = .85) # take top 85 percent

title: Filter player elements from the web — filter_players
text: Filter player elements web

title: Filter player elements from the web — filter_players
Filter player elements from the web — filter_players
text: data list api get_photos optional boolean: TRUE, gather photos FPL website suppress option boolean: FALSE, print print messages player photos found.

title: Filter player elements from the web — filter_players
text: returns data frame additional columns, player photo paths, team abbreviations

title: Filter player elements from the web — filter_players

what: Plot two variables with a linear square regression — fpl_plot
title: Plot two variables with a linear square regression — fpl_plot
text: Data spreadsheet can obtained premier league API. Using get_player_stats() followed filter_players() obtain current player records.

title: Plot two variables with a linear square regression — fpl_plot
code: fpl_plot(   spreadsheet,   x = "cost",   y = "points_per_game",   group = "names",   pos = NULL,   top_percent = NULL,   remove_player = NULL )

title: Plot two variables with a linear square regression — fpl_plot
text: spreadsheet input data frame, spreadsheet, path data x default: "cost", name column spreadsheet variable. Input flexible return shortest partial match. E.g., columns: "cost", "starting_cost", "cost" column selected shortest. y default: "points_per_game", name column spreadsheet variable, similar x variable. plotted y-axis group default: "names". Group column plot categories . Options: "names" - plots points players display names "teams" - plots points team icon "photos" - plots points player images pos default: NULL. Option filter players position. Options: "GKP" - Goalies, "FWD" - Forwards, "MID" - Midfielders, "DEF" - Defenders top_percent default: NULL. Option filter players total points percentage. Expects values 0 - 1. remove_player default: NULL. Input vector player(s) remove players plotting regression. E.g. input c("Haaland") remove table.

title: Plot two variables with a linear square regression — fpl_plot
text: Plot input parameters linear square regression regression coefficients. Additionally, prints filtered table.

title: Plot two variables with a linear square regression — fpl_plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ stats <- get_premier_stats() spreadsheet <- filter_players(stats) fpl_plot(spreadsheet, x = "cost", y = "total_points", group = "names", pos = "FWD") } # }
